I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 31 July 2006, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the second Governance 
and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II).1 The purpose of GACAP II is to improve ADB’s 
performance in the implementation of its governance and anticorruption policies in the sectors 
and subsectors where ADB is active. The implementation of GACAP II will enable ADB’s 
developing member countries (DMCs), in partnership with ADB, to design and deliver better-
quality projects and programs. ADB works with its DMCs to strengthen governance, develop 
capacity, and reduce vulnerability to corruption. This technical assistance is designed to support 
the implementation of GACAP II, and the related draft Capacity Development Medium-Term 
Framework and Action Plan.2 It will also continue ADB’s support for the ADB–Organization for 
Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Anticorruption Initiative for Asia and the 
Pacific  (the  ADB-OECD  Initiative).  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  TA  is  in 
Appendix 1.3 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Poor governance and corruption deter investment, waste resources and distort their 
allocation, undermine the credibility of public authorities, and increase insecurity. Moreover, the 
poor suffer most from the consequences of weak governance and corruption. Thus, to reduce 
poverty, governance must improve and corruption must diminish. Better governance means a 
more stable economy, more credible DMC policies, and less resource leakage. For effective 
poverty reduction, therefore, ADB and its DMCs must accord high priority to strengthening 
governance. 
 
3.  The Review of the Implementation of the Governance and Anticorruption Policies (the 
Review)4 was completed in December 2005. The Review concluded that the policies had been 
implemented only partially for two main reasons: first, the wide coverage of the policies has kept 
ADB  from  responding  effectively  to  systemic  governance  and  corruption  issues,  given  the 
competing  demands  for  its  limited  resources;  and,  second,  with  its  qualified  success  in 
mainstreaming the policies, ADB has not been able to mitigate the governance and corruption 
risks in sector work effectively. GACAP II is ADB’s response to the findings of the Review. It 
recognizes the importance of good governance, strong institutions, and reduced vulnerability to 
corruption as key prerequisites for sustainable development.  
 
4.  GACAP II reaffirms the findings of the Review and the need for action in the following 
critical areas: (i) filling the significant gaps in compliance with the governance and anticorruption 
policies and relevant operations manuals and project administration instructions; (ii) building 
stronger  partnerships  with  multilateral  and  bilateral  development  institutions,  particularly  in 
gaining access to country diagnostics and strengthening countries’ procurement systems and 
public financial management (PFM); (iii) applying institutional knowledge and country and sector 
diagnostics more effectively to determine focus and priorities; and (iv) instituting more flexible, 
longer-term institutional development arrangements to address systemic weaknesses in sector 
governance and corruption.

5.  In 2005, after the review of the poverty reduction strategy, ADB introduced capacity 
development  as  a  new  thematic  priority.  Consistent  with  the  good  practice  standards  for 
capacity development adopted recently by the OECD Development Assistance Committee, and 
ADB’s second medium-term strategy, the Capacity Development Medium-Term Framework and 
Action Plan (footnote 2) emphasizes the capacity of sector agencies and the networks and 
partnerships they engage with to deliver on their respective mandates. While numerous sector 
agencies have strived to develop capacity in the past, often with the support of ADB and other 
donors, capacity assessments have often not been systematic, and the ad hoc efforts that 
resulted may or may not have addressed core capacity issues. 
 
6.  The ADB-OECD Anti-Corruption Initiative for Asia and the Pacific was launched in 1999. 
Within its framework, countries from the region developed the Anti-corruption Action Plan for 
Asia-Pacific  (the  Action  Plan),  which  sets  goals  and  standards  for  sustainable  safeguards 
against corruption. The Action Plan is a landmark in regional cooperation against corruption. For 
the first time, Asia-Pacific countries have agreed to act together to combat corruption more 
effectively through high anticorruption standards, a mechanism for assessing progress, dialogue 
with  business  and  civil  society,  and  strong  regional  partnerships.  In  its  encouragement  of 
continual anticorruption reform, the Action Plan also enjoys significant and growing recognition 
from governments, international and donor organizations, civil society, and the private sector. 
The  government  of  17  countries  and  jurisdictions  in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region5 officially 
endorsed the Action Plan in 2001. The member countries of the Initiative have grown to 27,6 
and other countries in Asia-Pacific have expressed interest in endorsing the Action Plan. The 
ADB-OECD Initiative will begin its third implementation phase in 2007.  
 
7.  The proposed regional technical assistance will support the implementation of GACAP II 
and ADB’s capacity development action plan. It will also continue ADB’s support for the ADB-
OECD Initiative.  
 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
8.  The  proposed  regional  technical  assistance  will  have  three  interrelated  but  distinct 
components for governance, capacity development, and continuing support for the ADB-OECD 
Anticorruption Initiative. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The proposed technical assistance will improve awareness among DMCs of the potential 
impact of governance, institutional, and corruption risks on sustainable development. It will 
strengthen the governance, institutional, capacity, and anticorruption orientation of up to five 
country partnership strategies (CPSs) to be prepared in 2007 and 2008. 
 
 
                                                 
5  Bangladesh, Cook Islands, Fiji Islands, India, Indonesia, Japan, Republic of Korea, Kyrgyz Republic, Malaysia, 
Mongolia, Nepal, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Samoa, Singapore, and Vanuatu.  
6  The following joined after 2001: Kazakhstan (2002); Cambodia (2003); Hong Kong, China (2003); Australia (2003); 
Palau (2004); Viet Nam (2004); People’s Republic of China (2005); Thailand (2005); Macao, China (2006); and 
Sri Lanka (2006).

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Assessing public financial management, procurement systems, and corruption risks is 
an  important  starting  point  in  formulating  DMC  development  plans  and  ADB’s  CPSs.  The 
governance component will focus on the development of methodologies and tools for PFM and 
corruption risk assessments for CPSs, including subnational assessments where relevant and 
sector governance, institutional, and corruption risk assessments. These approaches will be 
tested, in partnership with DMCs, in up to five new CPSs, and in two sectors in each CPS.7 
Where practical, assessment tools will be based on currently available methodologies and will 
be adapted in consultation with development partners. 
 
11.  While GACAP Il has three thematic priorities—PFM, procurement, and corruption—
country procurement systems will not be assessed under the proposed technical assistance. 
Such an assessment is currently being made in coordination with the World Bank and other 
development  partners  and  will  be  supported  by  a  separate  technical  assistance  being 
implemented by the Central Operations Services Office.8 
 
12.  The capacity development (CD) component will also focus on the preparation of CPSs 
with  a  capacity  development  orientation.  Specific  activities  will  include  CD  baseline 
assessments and country orientation seminars. The proposed technical assistance will pilot-test 
these methodologies in up to two CPSs, and will support the development of sector-specific 
capacity development road maps. 
 
13.  The ADB-OECD Initiative strategy and work plan for 2007–2008 builds on the successful 
approach taken by the Action Plan signatories over the past years. The strategy articulates the 
Initiative’s vision, role, and goals for 2007–2008. It takes into account recent changes in the 
anticorruption landscape in the Asia-Pacific region to provide member countries with targeted 
assistance  in  their  fight  against  corruption.  Key  elements  of  the  strategy  are:  (i)  ensuring 
continual  review  of  the  progress  of  reform  under  the  Action  Plan,  (ii)  strengthening  and 
expanding  partnerships  in  the  fight  against  corruption,  and  (iii)  developing  capacity  for 
anticorruption activities. The third component of the proposed technical assistance will finance 
ADB’s continued support for this important flagship initiative in the fight against corruption in 
Asia and the Pacific.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA, estimated at $1.6 million, will be financed by a grant from ADB’s 
TA  funding  program.  The  TA  proceeds  will  cover  consulting  services,  regional  meetings, 
workshops, international travel, publications, and seminar and workshop costs. The detailed 
cost estimates for the proposed TA are in Appendix 2. For the anticorruption component, the 
cost estimates given in Appendix 2 reflect ADB’s costs only. Besides ADB financing, at least an 
equal amount will come from OECD, and bilateral assistance will be sought to support country-
specific activities (such as country thematic reviews and country roundtables).  
 
 
                                                 
7  As many as 17 CPSs are expected to be started in 2006 and 2007. Those of Afghanistan, Samoa, and Sri Lanka 
have been initially identified as possible test CPSs for initial GACAP ll application. 
8  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Supporting the Use of Country Procurement Systems. Manila (RETA 6317, 
$600,000, approved on 3 April).

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The proposed technical assistance will be implemented by ADB in consultation with 
selected country teams. The anticorruption component represents ADB’s ongoing support for 
the ADB-OECD Anticorruption Initiative. As has been the case in the past, both ADB and OECD 
will  have  separate  secretariat  functions  and  the  regional  technical  assistance  will  be 
implemented jointly under the guidance of the Initiative’s steering group.   
 
16.  The proposed technical assistance will require international consultants with skills in 
governance, public financial management, and anticorruption programs (25 person-months); 
organizational development (3 person-months); and institutional analysis (3 person-months). In 
addition, national governance consultants (54 person-months) and copy editors (30 person-days) 
will provide support. The proposed project will also strengthen local capacity providers (i.e., for 
workshops and CD assessments). Potential capacity providers will be identified during the 
inception mission and may be hired for the CD assessments and surveys. 
 
17.  Given the intermittence of the assignments and the variety of the skills required, all 
consultants will be hired as individuals by ADB according to its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. Outline terms of reference for the consultancy services are in Appendix 3. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
18.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $1,600,000 on a grant basis for the Governance and Capacity 
Development Initiative.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS1 
 
A.  Governance Component 
 
1.  The technical assistance will provide about 25 person months of international consulting 
services and 30 person months of domestic consulting services in public financial management, 
procurement, and anticorruption programs. Specific sector and country expertise will also be 
required. The specific consulting requirements will be refined further on the basis of the Country 
Partnership  Strategies  CPSs  and  sectors  selected  and  the  comparative  strengths  and 
weaknesses of each country team.  
 
2.  The  consultants  will  undertake  the  following  activities:  (i)  support  the  Capacity 
Development and Governance Division of the Regional Sustainable Development Department 
(RSCG) in consultations with development partners to develop and document a methodology for 
public financial management (PFM) and corruption risk assessments at national, subnational, 
and sector levels; (ii) support RSCG in consultations with country teams to develop an approach 
to implementing the second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II) in two 
sectors; (iii) together with the country team, assess the depth and quality of existing governance 
and anticorruption diagnostics at the national, subnational, and sector levels; (iv) together with 
developing member country (DMC) officials, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country 
team, undertake PFM and corruption risk assessments; (v) together with DMC officials and in 
consultation  with  ADB’s  country  team,  develop  risk  mitigation  strategies  at  the  national, 
subnational, and sector levels; (vi) provide relevant input into CPS documents; (vii) design a 
framework for assessing the proposed use of program lending for the relevant sector, national, 
or subnational government on the basis of an assessment of fiduciary and corruption risks of 
PFM; and (vi) update the methodology on the basis of experience gained. 
 
 
B.  Capacity Development Component 
3.  Two  international  consultants  will  provide  advisory  and  facilitation  services  in 
organizational and institutional development for up to 6 person-months. In addition, national 
capacity development (CD) providers will contribute to CD through surveys (for about 6 weeks 
per sector). More specific terms of reference for the consultants and an outline of the CD 
assessments will be prepared on the basis of feedback from the sector agencies after the 
inception mission.     
 
1.  Organizational  Development  Specialist/Lead  Consultant  (international,  3 
person-months) 
 
1.  The organizational development specialist/lead consultant will have a degree in social 
science, political science, or public administration and at least 15 years’ experience in designing 
and  implementing  capacity  development  programs  in  the  region,  preferably  in  the  social, 
agriculture, or rural development sector. The consultant will have contributed to the recent 
capacity  development  debate  and  should  have  experience  in  developing  and  applying 
organizational and network capacity assessment tools and stakeholder analysis at the sector 
level.  The  position  requires  strong  facilitation  and  communication  skills  and  long-term 
experience in the Asia and Pacific region.  
 
                                                 
1  Detailed terms of reference will be based on the specific requirements of the selected country teams.

2.  The consultant will undertake the following tasks: (i) support RSCG in consultations with 
regional departments to identify suitable sectors and countries, i.e., through presentations of 
ADB’s CD framework and regional TA concept in sector committees and country team meetings; 
(ii) prepare a long list of suitable sectors and DMCs indicating the level of regional department 
and DMC ownership and leadership, suitability for imminent country development strategies, 
CPSs, or loan operations, and feasibility in view of the limited budget for the component, for 
discussion with RSCG; (iii) prepare simple checklists for CD assessments in organizational and 
network development on the basis of a review of existing CD assessment tools and in close 
coordination with sector focal points and sector committees; (iv) conduct an inception mission to 
support two DMC agencies in the preparation and conduct of orientation sessions with key 
stakeholders, and in the identification of the scope of the assessments and key participants, 
including  in-country  capacity  providers,  and  identify  the  topics  of  the  surveys,  for  RSCG 
approval; (v) conduct a follow-up mission to support the two DMC agencies in the conduct of the 
CD assessments; (vi) edit the two assessments as requested by the DMC agency; (vii) support 
the DMC agency in the conduct of workshops to discuss the results of the assessments with key 
stakeholders and to come up with CD action plans; (viii) support the preparation of two DMC 
project Web sites; (ix) support one DMC agency in the presentation of the work in international 
conferences to be identified by RSCG; and (x) prepare a final report.      
 
2.  Institutional Development Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
3.  The  institutional  development  specialist  will  have  a  degree  in  economics,  political 
science, or public administration and will have worked in the public sector for at least 10 years. 
The  consultant  will  have  long-term  experience  in  designing  and  implementing  governance 
projects in the region, preferably in public financial management or decentralization, or both. 
The consultant will be familiar with the recent capacity development debate and will have 
experience in applying institutional capacity assessment tools either at the local government 
level  or  in  the  enabling  environment  of  sectors.  Experience  in  the  urban  development  or 
infrastructure  sector  would  be  an  asset.  The  consultant  will  have  proven  experience  with 
facilitative approaches that strengthen ownership and leadership of the executing agency and 
will be familiar with methods of adopting inclusive approaches to a variety of stakeholders. The 
position requires long-term experience in the Asia and Pacific region.     
 
4.  The consultant will undertake the following tasks: (i) support RSCG in consultations with 
regional departments to identify target sectors; (ii) contribute to the preparation of a long list of 
suitable sectors indicating the level of regional department and DMC ownership; (iii) prepare 
simple checklists for CD assessments in the area of institutional capacity development tools in 
close coordination with sector focal points and sector committees; (iv) conduct an inception 
mission to support two DMC agencies in the preparation and conduct of orientation sessions 
with  key  stakeholders,  and  the  identification  of  the  scope  of  the  assessments  and  key 
participants, including in-country capacity providers, and identify the topics of the surveys for the 
approval of RSCG; (v) conduct a follow-up mission to support the two DMC agencies in the 
conduct of the CD assessments; (vi) edit the two assessments as required by the DMC agency; 
(vii) support the conduct of workshops to discuss the results of the assessments with key 
stakeholders and to develop CD action plans; (viii) prepare an ADB project Web site and 
knowledge product on the experiences gained through the project; (ix) support the preparation 
of DMC agency Web sites; (x) support one DMC agency in the presentation of its work at an 
international conference identified by ADB; and (xi)report regularly on progress to the lead 
consultant.

C.  Anticorruption Component 
6.  The proposed TA will provide secretariat and publication expertise to the ADB-OECD 
Anticorruption Initiative as follows: 
 
  1.  Governance and Anticorruption Specialist (national, 24 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant must have a technical background and familiarity with, and relevant 
experience in, the governance and anticorruption activities of ADB and in the Asia-Pacific region 
to be able to provide professional, research, and administrative support to RSCG in managing 
the initiative. The specialist will (i) organize and provide logistical support for steering group 
meetings, regional conferences, and training seminars; (ii) provide technical and administrative 
assistance in organizing and coordinating with development agencies and partner institutions on 
anticorruption initiatives in the Asia-Pacific region; (iii) coordinate with ADB resident missions 
and heads of government of DMCs to identify DMC participants in regional policy dialogues, in-
country consultations, steering group meetings, and anticorruption workshops; (iv) communicate 
with  proposed  resource  speakers,  participants,  and  representatives  of  international 
organizations at bilateral meetings, ensure their availability, and coordinate their papers for 
presentation; (v) assist in the preparation of speeches, papers, presentation materials, and 
seminar tool kits for steering group meetings, conferences, and training seminars; (vi) assist 
DMC participants and resource persons invited by ADB with their travel arrangements and other 
matters related to their participation at meetings, dialogues, and workshops; (vii) coordinate with 
partner  institutions  and  be  a  part  of  the  secretariat  that  will  oversee  logistics  and  other 
administrative matters; (viii) provide research assistance relating to anticorruption issues and 
prepare responses to queries and concerns of DMC governments, anticorruption agencies, and 
international institutions; and (ix) provide initial editing and coordinate with the copy editor and 
contributors regarding the editing, revisions, and finalization of the training seminar papers and 
proceedings, review the editing of the seminar papers, prepare the necessary requirements, 
and supervise the typesetting and printing of publications. The consultant may participate in 
selected workshops and meetings associated with the ADB-OECD Initiative. 
 
  2.  Copy Editors (various, 30 days) 
 
8.  The consultants, to be hired as needed, will have editorial experience and a thorough 
knowledge of the publishing requirements of ADB. The consultants will (i) copy-edit selected 
conference  papers  and  publications  to  improve  their  overall  presentation  and  enhance 
readability by ensuring consistency in style and format among the various sections according to 
ADB’s Handbook on Style and Usage; (ii) incorporate comments and required corrections in the 
text; (iii) edit preliminary and other materials (foreword, executive summary, list of participants, 
etc);  and  (iv)  prepare  manuscripts  in  Microsoft  Word  format,  ensuring  readiness  for  final 
typesetting and formatting by ADB.
